user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskPrepare:
```c
static int32 OS_TaskPrepare(osal_id_t task_id, osal_task_entry *entrypt)
{
    int32                      return_code;
    OS_object_token_t          token;
    OS_task_internal_record_t *task;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK, task_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        task = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_task_table, token);

        return_code = OS_TaskMatch_Impl(&token);
        *entrypt    = task->entry_function_pointer;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_TaskRegister_Impl(task_id);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* Give event callback to the application */
        return_code = OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_TASK_STARTUP, task_id, NULL);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *entrypt = NULL;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskPrepare:
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_TaskMatch_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    if (pthread_equal(pthread_self(), impl->id) == 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
int32 OS_TaskRegister_Impl(osal_id_t global_task_id)
{
    int32                    return_code;
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t arg;
    int                      old_state;
    int                      old_type;

    /*
     * Set cancel state=ENABLED, type=DEFERRED
     * This should be the default for new threads, but
     * setting explicitly to be sure that a pthread_join()
     * will work as expected in case this thread is deleted.
     */
    pthread_setcancelstate(PTHREAD_CANCEL_ENABLE, &old_state);
    pthread_setcanceltype(PTHREAD_CANCEL_DEFERRED, &old_type);

    memset(&arg, 0, sizeof(arg));

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    arg.id = global_task_id;

    return_code = pthread_setspecific(POSIX_GlobalVars.ThreadKey, arg.opaque_arg);
    if (return_code == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        OS_DEBUG("OS_TaskRegister_Impl failed during pthread_setspecific() error=%s\n", strerror(return_code));
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_NotifyEvent(OS_Event_t event, osal_id_t object_id, void *data)
{
    int32 status;

    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler != NULL)
    {
        status = OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler(event, object_id, data);
    }
    else
    {
        status = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return status;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_task_internal_record_t OS_task_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
typedef struct
{
    char            task_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    size_t          stack_size;
    osal_priority_t priority;
    osal_task_entry entry_function_pointer;
    osal_task_entry delete_hook_pointer;
    void *          entry_arg;
    osal_stackptr_t stack_pointer;
} OS_task_internal_record_t
...
typedef osal_task((*osal_task_entry)(void))
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK 0x01
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragment in the provided sources assigns to a function parameter itself. Summary of checks performed:

- OS_TaskPrepare(osal_id_t task_id, osal_task_entry *entrypt): The function writes to *entrypt (two assignments: *entrypt = task->entry_function_pointer; and *entrypt = NULL;). Per Rule 17.8 the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified; modifying the pointed-to object is allowed. The pointer variable entrypt is never reassigned (no entrypt = ...), and task_id (a non-pointer parameter) is never assigned to. Therefore this function does not violate Rule 17.8.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById(..., OS_object_token_t *token): The routine modifies fields of *token (token->obj_idx, token->obj_id) which is permitted. The pointer parameter token itself is not reassigned.

- OS_TaskMatch_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token): The parameter is const-qualified and is only dereferenced; there is no assignment to token itself.

- OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token): The function calls another routine with token but does not assign to the token parameter itself.

- OS_TaskRegister_Impl(osal_id_t global_task_id): This non-pointer parameter is only read (copied into a local union member); it is not modified.

- OS_NotifyEvent(OS_Event_t event, osal_id_t object_id, void *data): The function forwards the data pointer to the event handler; it does not reassign the parameter data.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) macro: Expands to (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))]). The macro takes the address of the macro argument; it does not perform any assignment to the argument. Usage sites in the provided code either pass a local token variable or dereference a pointer parameter (e.g. *token). Taking the address of *token yields the original pointer value, but no pointer parameter is reassigned.

No other fragments in the supplied code perform assignments like parameter = ... or pointer_parameter = ... which would be a direct Rule 17.8 violation. Note: functions whose full bodies are not shown (e.g., OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex) could contain parameter reassignments internally; those were not provided and therefore not flagged. Based on the provided code, there are no suspicious fragments requiring investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
